results.title: Buster Keaton rides again
results.creator_credit: John Spotton, Julian Biggs and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In this film Buster Keaton rides across Canada on a railway scooter and, between times, rests in a specially appointed passenger coach where he and Mrs Keaton lived during their Canadian film assignment. This film is about how Buster Keaton made a Canadian travel film, “The Railrodder”. In this informal study the comedian regales the film crew with anecdotes of a lifetime in show business. Excerpts from his silent slapstick films are shown. Awards: Seven, including Venice; New York; Melbourne; Milan. Commentary by Donald Brittain.

results.title: Bushy, the squirrel
results.brief_description: Designed for use in primary classes. Eight-year-old Steve discovers a squirrel frightening away the birds in his yard. He and his father find the squirrel’s home in a tree in the woods. Making trips to the woods to see Bushy, they discover other forest animals. With patience and perseverance Steve teaches the squirrel to eat from his hand.

results.title: Bushtrak
results.creator_credit: John Kingsford-Smith, Ampol Petroleum Ltd and Kingcroft Productions
results.brief_description: Shows the layout of an obstacle track designed to test physical prowess. Obstacles include climbing nets, climbing bars and swinging ropes. Commentary by Paul Ricketts.

results.title: The Bushman goes home
results.creator_credit: Eric Bedford and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: A cattle station owner makes the long journey from his vast cattle station on the Gulf of Carpentaria to visit Melbourne and the cattle saleyards. He then flies back via the cattle fattening plains of New South Wales. Narrated by Nigel Lovell.

results.title: Bushfire brigade
results.creator_credit: Eric Thompson and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Illustrates the danger of bushfires and describes how bodies such as the Volunteer Bushfire Brigade and the Forestry Firefighting gangs are organised to prevent and fight bushfires.

results.title: Bush harvest
results.creator_credit: W. H. Shepherd, John Martin-Jones and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Eucalyptus oil is distilled from the leaves of certain types of Australian eucalyptus trees. The film shows this being done by men who live and work in the bush and also some of the scientific research being carried out in order to determine the uses to which the different types of oil may be put. Photography: Frank Bagnall.

results.title: A Burn's best friend
results.creator_credit: British Petroleum and St John Ambulance Australia
results.brief_description: This film deals with burns caused by sun, chemicals, steam and fire, stressing that COLD WATER is the best first aid treatment where injury is susceptible to infection. It explains the medical principle behind this treatment.

results.title: Burnout
results.creator_credit: J. Gary Mitchell, John McDonald and M T I Teleprograms
results.brief_description: A series of dramatized sequences illustrate different types of ‘burnout’ that occur in work situations. Shows the frustrations which create it, varying responses and shows how communication combats burnout. Includes cameos from actor Pee Wee Herman as a therapist, pop star and french film actor.

results.title: The Burnie story
results.creator_credit: Associated Pulp and Paper Manufacturers and Cine Service
results.brief_description: The township of Burnie on the north-west coast of Tasmania with a population of 14,000 is the centre of the thriving pulp and paper manufacturing industry. This industry started in 1936 and produces from the forests in the surrounding country, not only timber for the building industry but from the timber waste all types of cardboard, and wrapping paper and even high-grade printing paper. The film shows the up-to-date and powerful machinery which is used from the time a tree is felled until the final paper product is shipped from the Burnie wharves. Afforestation is maintained to ensure the raw material will not be exhausted. Photography: Geoffrey Thompson. Narrated by Ray Chapman.
